title: Leviticus Chapter 26 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Leviticus chapter 26 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Leviticus Chapter 26 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Leviticus Chapter 26.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 26:1, what are the Israelites commanded not to make or set up in their land?
options: Idols and graven images
Altars of gold
Fountains and wells
Walls and towers
questions.correctAnswer: Idols and graven images
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:1 commands the Israelites not to make idols, graven images, standing images, or stone images to bow down to.

questions.question: What are the Israelites instructed to keep and reverence in Leviticus 26:2?
options: Sabbaths and the sanctuary
Feasts and sacrifices
The law and the prophets
The kings and the judges
questions.correctAnswer: Sabbaths and the sanctuary
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:2 instructs the people to keep God's sabbaths and reverence His sanctuary.

questions.question: What will God give the Israelites if they walk in His statutes and keep His commandments as stated in Leviticus 26:4?
options: Rain in due season and fruitful land
Gold and silver treasures
Victory over all nations
Endless harvests without toil
questions.correctAnswer: Rain in due season and fruitful land
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:4 promises rain in due season and that the land shall yield its increase if the Israelites obey God's commandments.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 26:6, what will God give in the land if the people obey Him?
options: Peace, safety, and removal of evil beasts
Wealth, fame, and long life
Fire from heaven and storms
Kings and judges
questions.correctAnswer: Peace, safety, and removal of evil beasts
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:6 states that God will give peace, safety, and will rid evil beasts from the land if the people obey Him.

questions.question: In Leviticus 26:8, how many shall chase an hundred, and how many shall put ten thousand to flight?
options: Five shall chase an hundred, and an hundred shall put ten thousand to flight
Ten shall chase an hundred, and fifty shall put ten thousand to flight
One shall chase ten, and twenty shall put a thousand to flight
Twenty shall chase fifty, and fifty shall put a thousand to flight
questions.correctAnswer: Five shall chase an hundred, and an hundred shall put ten thousand to flight
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:8 says five of you shall chase an hundred, and an hundred of you shall put ten thousand to flight.

questions.question: What will God set among the Israelites according to Leviticus 26:11?
options: His tabernacle
A great king
A mighty army
A golden altar
questions.correctAnswer: His tabernacle
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:11 says God will set His tabernacle among the Israelites and His soul shall not abhor them.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 26:13, who brought the Israelites out of the land of Egypt?
options: The LORD your God
Moses
Aaron
Pharaoh
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD your God
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:13 states that the LORD your God brought the Israelites out of Egypt to make them free.

questions.question: What will happen if the Israelites despise God's statutes and break His covenant, according to Leviticus 26:16?
options: God will appoint terror, consumption, and burning ague upon them
They will be blessed with riches
Their enemies will be destroyed immediately
They will build many cities
questions.correctAnswer: God will appoint terror, consumption, and burning ague upon them
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:16 warns that if the Israelites break the covenant, God will appoint terror, consumption, and burning ague that consume their eyes and cause sorrow of heart.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 26:22, what will God send among the Israelites if they do not listen?
options: Wild beasts that will rob children and destroy cattle
Fire and brimstone
Floods and earthquakes
Angels of peace
questions.correctAnswer: Wild beasts that will rob children and destroy cattle
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:22 states that God will send wild beasts among the people to rob their children and destroy their cattle if they disobey.

questions.question: What will happen when God breaks the staff of their bread, according to Leviticus 26:26?
options: Ten women shall bake bread in one oven and deliver it by weight but they will not be satisfied
Bread will be plentiful and abundant
The people will feast every day
The land will produce double harvests
questions.correctAnswer: Ten women shall bake bread in one oven and deliver it by weight but they will not be satisfied
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:26 describes that when the staff of bread is broken, ten women will bake in one oven and deliver bread by weight, and the people will eat but not be satisfied.

questions.question: True or False: Leviticus 26:29 states that the Israelites will eat the flesh of their sons and daughters if they do not obey God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:29 explicitly states that the Israelites shall eat the flesh of their sons and daughters if they walk contrary to God.

questions.question: True or False: According to Leviticus 26:33, God will scatter the Israelites among the heathen and make their land desolate.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:33 says God will scatter the Israelites among the heathen, bring a sword after them, and make their land desolate.

questions.question: True or False: Leviticus 26:44 says that God will utterly destroy the Israelites and break His covenant with them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:44 states that God will not cast them away or break His covenant with them, even when they are in the land of their enemies.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Leviticus 26:12: 'And I will walk among you, and will be your _______, and ye shall be my people.'
options: God
King
Friend
Leader
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:12 says God will walk among the Israelites and be their God, and they shall be His people.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Leviticus 26:40: 'If they shall confess their iniquity, and the iniquity of their fathers, with their trespass which they trespassed against me, and that also they have walked contrary unto _____;'
options: me
their neighbors
the law
the priests
questions.correctAnswer: me
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:40 speaks of confessing their iniquity and that they have walked contrary unto God (me).

medium.title: Leviticus Chapter 26 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Leviticus Chapter 26 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with maintaining integrity at work. Based on Leviticus 26, what principle about obedience and blessings can you share to encourage perseverance?
options: Obedience to God's commandments brings fruitful work and safety.
Ignoring God's laws leads to immediate punishment without hope.
Success comes only from personal effort, not from God.
Blessings are guaranteed regardless of our obedience.
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God's commandments brings fruitful work and safety.
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:3-6 teaches that if we walk in God's statutes and keep His commandments, He will bless our work with rain, increase, peace, and safety.

questions.question: How does Leviticus 26 teach about God’s faithfulness to His covenant even when His people face consequences for disobedience?
options: God remembers His covenant and will not utterly destroy His people.
God immediately rejects and abandons those who disobey.
God rewards disobedience with blessings.
God’s covenant depends on people’s perfect obedience.
questions.correctAnswer: God remembers His covenant and will not utterly destroy His people.
questions.explanation: Verses 44-45 affirm that despite punishment, God will not cast away or break His covenant with His people, showing His steadfast faithfulness.

questions.question: A believer feels discouraged by trials and wonders why they are happening. According to Leviticus 26, what biblical truth about discipline and restoration can you share?
options: Discipline is a consequence of sin, but God offers restoration when people confess and humble themselves.
Trials are random and have no connection to obedience or sin.
God only disciplines the wicked and never His own people.
Restoration is impossible once God’s punishment begins.
questions.correctAnswer: Discipline is a consequence of sin, but God offers restoration when people confess and humble themselves.
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:40-42 explains that if people confess their iniquity and humble their hearts, God will remember His covenant and restore them.

questions.question: How does Leviticus 26 instruct believers to handle temptation to idolatry in daily life?
options: Avoid making or bowing to idols because God is the only Lord.
Create images to help remember God’s power.
Idolatry is acceptable if done secretly.
God tolerates idols if they bring comfort.
questions.correctAnswer: Avoid making or bowing to idols because God is the only Lord.
questions.explanation: Verse 1 commands not to make idols or images to bow down to, emphasizing exclusive worship of God.

questions.question: A Christian parent wants to teach their children about the importance of keeping God's commands. Based on Leviticus 26, what promise can encourage steadfastness?
options: God will multiply and make them fruitful if they obey His statutes.
Children will never face consequences for disobedience.
God’s blessings are unrelated to obedience.
Obedience only benefits the individual, not future generations.
questions.correctAnswer: God will multiply and make them fruitful if they obey His statutes.
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:9 promises fruitfulness and multiplication as a result of God’s respect for those who obey Him.

questions.question: How does Leviticus 26 teach about contentment and gratitude in times of blessing?
options: Enjoying the full bread and safe dwelling shows God's provision for grateful hearts.
Blessings are to be taken for granted as normal.
Gratitude is unnecessary if we have abundance.
Contentment comes only from material wealth.
questions.correctAnswer: Enjoying the full bread and safe dwelling shows God's provision for grateful hearts.
questions.explanation: Verses 5-6 describe eating bread to the full and dwelling safely as blessings from God, encouraging gratitude and contentment.

questions.question: True or False: According to Leviticus 26, God promises peace in the land and removal of evil beasts to those who obey Him.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:6 clearly states God will give peace, remove evil beasts, and protect the land for those who keep His commandments.

questions.question: True or False: Leviticus 26 teaches that God’s discipline can include famine, wild beasts, and captivity for disobedient people.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 16, 22, and 33 describe various judgments such as famine, wild beasts, and scattering among nations as consequences of disobedience.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Leviticus 26 teaches that if the people confess their iniquity and humble their hearts, then God will remember His ________ with their ancestors.
options: covenant
punishment
anger
commandments
questions.correctAnswer: covenant
questions.explanation: Verse 42 states that when people confess and humble their hearts, God will remember His covenant with Jacob, Isaac, and Abraham.

questions.question: What lesson about humility and repentance can be drawn from Leviticus 26 regarding restoration after failure?
options: Humble hearts and confession lead to God’s mercy and remembering His covenant.
Pride and denial prevent restoration no matter what.
Restoration happens automatically without repentance.
God punishes without any chance for forgiveness.
questions.correctAnswer: Humble hearts and confession lead to God’s mercy and remembering His covenant.
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:40-42 teaches that confession and humbling lead God to restore His covenant relationship.

questions.question: How does Leviticus 26 encourage believers to maintain a faithful prayer life and devotion?
options: By promising God's presence among them and walking with them as their God.
By suggesting prayer is unnecessary if they obey.
By focusing only on rituals without heart devotion.
By relying on their own strength without God.
questions.correctAnswer: By promising God's presence among them and walking with them as their God.
questions.explanation: Verses 11-12 assure God’s presence among His people and that He will walk with them, encouraging faithful devotion and prayer.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 26, what is a consequence of breaking God’s covenant and despising His statutes in family and community life?
options: Sowing seeds in vain and enemies consuming the harvest.
Experiencing immediate wealth and honor.
Receiving blessings regardless of behavior.
Living without any fear or trouble.
questions.correctAnswer: Sowing seeds in vain and enemies consuming the harvest.
questions.explanation: Verses 16-17 describe consequences like sowing in vain and enemies eating the harvest as outcomes of covenant-breaking.

questions.question: What does Leviticus 26 teach about perseverance through trials and trusting in God’s ultimate justice?
options: Though trials and enemies prevail temporarily, God’s covenant promises restoration after repentance.
Trials mean God has abandoned His people permanently.
Believers should give up when facing enemies.
Justice is only human and not from God.
questions.correctAnswer: Though trials and enemies prevail temporarily, God’s covenant promises restoration after repentance.
questions.explanation: Verses 33-45 show that despite scattering and judgment, God remembers His covenant and offers restoration upon repentance.

questions.question: How does Leviticus 26 instruct believers to show love for neighbors and serve others in the community?
options: By living in obedience to God’s statutes which promote peace and safety among them.
By focusing only on personal gain and ignoring community needs.
By tolerating idolatry and disobedience in others.
By isolating themselves from neighbors and community.
questions.correctAnswer: By living in obedience to God’s statutes which promote peace and safety among them.
questions.explanation: Verses 5-6 describe dwelling safely and peace in the land as results of obedience, reflecting love and service to neighbors.

questions.question: What biblical principle about work ethic and honesty can be learned from Leviticus 26 concerning God’s blessings?
options: God blesses honest work with abundant harvest and safety when His commandments are followed.
Work ethic is irrelevant to God’s blessings.
Dishonest gain is acceptable if it leads to success.
God’s blessings are random and unrelated to obedience.
questions.correctAnswer: God blesses honest work with abundant harvest and safety when His commandments are followed.
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:4-6 highlights blessings such as rain, fruitful trees, and safe dwelling as rewards for obedience, encouraging honest work.

hard.title: Leviticus Chapter 26 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Leviticus Chapter 26.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 26:4-6, what are the promised blessings if the Israelites walk in God's statutes and keep His commandments?
options: Rain in due season, peace in the land, and safety from enemies
Wealth and many children
Immediate conquest of all neighboring nations
Freedom from all labor
questions.correctAnswer: Rain in due season, peace in the land, and safety from enemies
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:4-6 promises rain in its season, fruitful land, peace with no fear from enemies or beasts as blessings for obedience.

questions.question: Leviticus 26:13 emphasizes God's role in delivering Israel from Egypt. What is the significance of this statement in the context of covenant theology?
options: It reaffirms God's identity as Redeemer and covenant Keeper
It introduces a new covenant distinct from the Mosaic covenant
It predicts the exile to Babylon
It focuses on Israel's military strength
questions.correctAnswer: It reaffirms God's identity as Redeemer and covenant Keeper
questions.explanation: Verse 13 reminds Israel that God brought them out of Egypt and broke their yoke, underscoring His faithful covenant relationship.

questions.question: In Leviticus 26:14-39, a series of punishments are outlined for disobedience. Which literary device is prominently used to structure these warnings?
options: Progressive intensification through repetition and numerical increase
Chiasm focusing on mercy in the center
Parallelism contrasting blessings and curses
Allegory representing Israel's journey
questions.correctAnswer: Progressive intensification through repetition and numerical increase
questions.explanation: The text uses repetition of 'seven times' and escalating punishments to emphasize severity, a common Hebrew literary device.

questions.question: Leviticus 26:21 mentions 'seven times more plagues.' What is the symbolic significance of the number seven in biblical literature?
options: Completeness or perfection in divine judgment
A random number with no symbolic meaning
Represents a week of days only
Symbolizes mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Completeness or perfection in divine judgment
questions.explanation: The number seven often signifies completeness in Hebrew thought, indicating full and perfect judgment.

questions.question: Which of the following consequences described in Leviticus 26 foreshadows the Babylonian exile described in 2 Kings and Jeremiah?
options: Scattering among nations and desolation of land and cities
Immediate destruction by fire
Permanent loss of the covenant
Transformation of the temple into a palace
questions.correctAnswer: Scattering among nations and desolation of land and cities
questions.explanation: Verses 33 and 34 speak of scattering and land desolation, paralleling the Babylonian exile themes in later prophetic books.

questions.question: Leviticus 26:11-12 uses the phrase 'I will set my tabernacle among you.' How does this relate to the New Testament concept of God's presence?
options: It prefigures God's dwelling in believers through the Holy Spirit
It refers exclusively to the physical tabernacle in the wilderness
It foreshadows the destruction of the temple
It is a metaphor for Israel’s political power
questions.correctAnswer: It prefigures God's dwelling in believers through the Holy Spirit
questions.explanation: God's promise to dwell among His people anticipates the New Testament teaching of God's Spirit living within believers (cf. John 14:17).

questions.question: In Leviticus 26:29, what extreme punishment is described that reflects the severity of covenant breach, and how does this compare to other biblical accounts of desperation?
options: Eating the flesh of sons and daughters; parallels the siege of Jerusalem in Lamentations
Exile to a foreign land with no return
Immediate death by plague
Loss of the priesthood
questions.correctAnswer: Eating the flesh of sons and daughters; parallels the siege of Jerusalem in Lamentations
questions.explanation: Verse 29's horrifying imagery is echoed in Lamentations 4:10, depicting extreme famine and judgment during siege.

questions.question: True or False: Leviticus 26 teaches that even in judgment, God will not utterly reject Israel or break His covenant with them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:44 assures that despite punishment, God will not utterly cast away or break His covenant with Israel.

questions.question: The phrase 'walk contrary unto me' appears multiple times in Leviticus 26. What does this phrase signify in the covenant context?
options: Disobedience and rebellion against God's commandments
Physical movement away from the tabernacle
A ritual purification process
An agricultural cycle
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience and rebellion against God's commandments
questions.explanation: The phrase indicates willful rejection of God's law, central to the covenant stipulations outlined in this chapter.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the theological theme emphasized by Leviticus 26:40-45 regarding repentance?
options: Confession and humility lead to restoration of covenant blessings
Repentance is unnecessary once judgment begins
Only national repentance matters, not individual
God’s covenant is conditional solely on sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: Confession and humility lead to restoration of covenant blessings
questions.explanation: Verses 40-45 teach that acknowledging sin and humbling the heart results in God remembering the covenant and restoring Israel.

questions.question: The command in Leviticus 26:2 to 'keep my sabbaths' has a dual significance. Historically, what were these sabbaths, and how do they symbolically relate to later biblical themes?
options: Sabbath years for rest of land and people; symbolize ultimate rest in God’s kingdom
Daily worship times; symbolize angels' worship
Annual sacrifices; symbolize Christ's atonement
Feasts of harvest; symbolize the end of the world
questions.correctAnswer: Sabbath years for rest of land and people; symbolize ultimate rest in God’s kingdom
questions.explanation: The sabbaths include sabbatical years for land rest (Leviticus 25), prefiguring spiritual rest promised in Hebrews 4.

questions.question: Leviticus 26:10 mentions 'ye shall eat old store, and bring forth the old because of the new.' What agricultural principle does this illustrate, and how might it reflect Israel's relationship with God?
options: Abundance and provision beyond scarcity; God's sustaining faithfulness
Scarcity forcing reliance on stored food; divine judgment
Seasonal planting cycles; covenant renewal
Harvest festivals; communal celebration
questions.correctAnswer: Abundance and provision beyond scarcity; God's sustaining faithfulness
questions.explanation: This verse illustrates God's blessing of abundance so the old crops are still eaten when new crops arrive, symbolizing ongoing provision.

questions.question: In the context of ancient Near Eastern treaties, how does Leviticus 26 function as a suzerain-vassal treaty form?
options: It outlines blessings for obedience and curses for disobedience like treaty stipulations
It is a historical narrative without legal elements
It focuses only on worship rituals
It demands unconditional loyalty without consequences
questions.correctAnswer: It outlines blessings for obedience and curses for disobedience like treaty stipulations
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26 resembles ancient treaties by promising blessings for loyalty and curses for rebellion, fitting suzerain-vassal treaty structure.

questions.question: Leviticus 26:30 describes God’s soul abhorring Israel because of idolatry. How does this anthropomorphic language deepen the understanding of God's relationship with His people?
options: It expresses God's personal and emotional involvement with Israel’s faithfulness
It implies God is limited by human emotions
It indicates God’s detachment from human affairs
It refers to ritual impurity only
questions.correctAnswer: It expresses God's personal and emotional involvement with Israel’s faithfulness
questions.explanation: The use of 'soul shall abhor' conveys God’s deep displeasure and relational commitment, showing a covenant relationship beyond legalism.

questions.question: True or False: The curses in Leviticus 26 are irreversible and leave no hope for restoration.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:40-45 clearly offers hope of restoration through confession and humility, showing curses are conditional and reversible.

theological.title: Leviticus Chapter 26 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Leviticus Chapter 26 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 26, what is the consequence promised if the Israelites walk in God's statutes and keep His commandments?
options: The land shall yield its increase and peace will be in the land
They will be cast out of the land
They will suffer famine and defeat by enemies
Their children will be taken captive
questions.correctAnswer: The land shall yield its increase and peace will be in the land
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:3-6 promises blessings including rain in due season, fruitful land, and peace if the Israelites obey God's commandments. This theme is consistent with Deuteronomy 28:1-14, Psalm 85:10, Isaiah 32:17, and Matthew 6:33.

questions.question: What does God say He will do among the Israelites if they obey Him, according to Leviticus 26?
options: Set His tabernacle among them and be their God
Send prophets to warn them
Bring judgment upon their enemies
Hide His face from them
questions.correctAnswer: Set His tabernacle among them and be their God
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:11-12 states that God will set His tabernacle among the Israelites and walk among them as their God, which is echoed in Exodus 25:8, John 1:14, 2 Corinthians 6:16, and Revelation 21:3.

questions.question: What is one of the punishments listed in Leviticus 26 if the people break God's covenant and refuse to obey?
options: Terror, consumption, and burning ague
Immediate destruction by fire
Permanent exile without hope
Freedom from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Terror, consumption, and burning ague
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:16 specifies these afflictions as part of God's discipline for covenant breaking. Similar judgments are found in Deuteronomy 28:22, Jeremiah 15:2, Psalm 91:5, and Hebrews 12:6 showing God’s corrective discipline.

questions.question: Leviticus 26:14-15 warns against which specific attitude towards God's statutes and commandments?
options: Despising the statutes and abhorring the judgments
Joyfully obeying the commandments
Teaching the statutes to others
Praying daily for guidance
questions.correctAnswer: Despising the statutes and abhorring the judgments
questions.explanation: Verses 14-15 warn that despising God's statutes and abhorring His judgments leads to breaking the covenant, which brings consequences. This is echoed in Proverbs 1:29, Psalm 78:10, Hebrews 10:29, and Romans 1:30.

questions.question: What does Leviticus 26 say will happen to the land if the Israelites do not observe the Sabbath of the land?
options: The land will lie desolate and enjoy its Sabbaths while they are in exile
The land will become more fertile
The land will be given to their enemies
The land will produce twice as much fruit
questions.correctAnswer: The land will lie desolate and enjoy its Sabbaths while they are in exile
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:34-35 teaches that the land must rest on its Sabbaths, and if neglected, it will rest during the exile. This theological principle is supported by Exodus 23:10-11, 2 Chronicles 36:21, Jeremiah 17:24-27, and Hebrews 4:9-10.

questions.question: What does God promise to remember if the people confess their iniquity and humble their hearts, according to Leviticus 26?
options: His covenant with Jacob, Isaac, and Abraham
Their past sins and punish them
Their enemies’ victories
Their exile forever
questions.correctAnswer: His covenant with Jacob, Isaac, and Abraham
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:40-42 explains that God will remember His covenant with the patriarchs if the people confess and humble themselves. This covenant faithfulness is echoed in Genesis 17:7, Psalm 105:8, Isaiah 54:10, and Romans 11:28-29.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Leviticus 26:13 says, 'I am the LORD your God, which brought you forth out of the land of Egypt, that ye should not be their ________.'
options: bondmen
priests
enemies
strangers
questions.correctAnswer: bondmen
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:13 states God freed Israel to prevent them from being bondmen (slaves). This deliverance theme is central in Exodus 6:6, Deuteronomy 5:15, Luke 4:18, and Galatians 5:1.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 26, how many times will God punish the people if they refuse to repent after initial discipline?
options: Seven times more
Three times more
Ten times more
No additional punishment
questions.correctAnswer: Seven times more
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:18, 21, 24, and 28 repeatedly state God will punish seven times more for persistent disobedience, illustrating the intensification of judgment. The number seven symbolizes completeness as in Genesis 4:15, Revelation 15:1, and Daniel 4:16.

questions.question: What is one of the signs of God's abhorrence toward Israel for their idolatry as described in Leviticus 26?
options: Casting their carcasses upon the carcasses of their idols
Making them priests of their idols
Blessing their idols
Hiding His face forever
questions.correctAnswer: Casting their carcasses upon the carcasses of their idols
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:30 shows God's abhorrence by desecrating the bodies of idolaters alongside their idols. This demonstrates His holiness and judgment, parallel to Ezekiel 6:13, Psalm 79:1-5, Habakkuk 2:8, and Revelation 9:20.

questions.question: What does Leviticus 26:29 warn as a horrific consequence of persistent disobedience?
options: Eating the flesh of their sons and daughters
Being enslaved by foreign nations
Losing their land permanently
Living in constant fear
questions.correctAnswer: Eating the flesh of their sons and daughters
questions.explanation: Verse 29 describes cannibalism as a curse for extreme judgment, illustrating the severity of God's wrath. This is referenced in 2 Kings 6:28-29, Jeremiah 19:9, Lamentations 4:10, and Ezekiel 5:10.

questions.question: What does God say He will do if the people continue to reject Him after multiple judgments, according to Leviticus 26?
options: Walk contrary to them in fury and chastise them seven times for their sins
Send a final flood to destroy them
Remove His covenant forever
Forgive them immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Walk contrary to them in fury and chastise them seven times for their sins
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:28 teaches that persistent rebellion results in God walking contrary in fury and administering sevenfold chastisement. This principle of divine wrath is supported by Nahum 1:2, Romans 1:18, Hebrews 10:31, and Revelation 16:1.

questions.question: What does Leviticus 26:44 affirm about God's commitment to Israel despite their failings?
options: God will not cast them away or break His covenant with them
God will reject them utterly
God will replace them with another people
God will forget His promises
questions.correctAnswer: God will not cast them away or break His covenant with them
questions.explanation: Verse 44 affirms God's enduring covenant faithfulness despite Israel's sins, consistent with Psalm 89:34, Jeremiah 31:35-37, Romans 11:29, and 2 Timothy 2:13.

questions.question: Leviticus 26:7-8 describes a miraculous military victory where a few Israelites will defeat many enemies. What is the ratio given?
options: Five of you shall chase a hundred, and a hundred of you shall put ten thousand to flight
One shall defeat ten
Ten shall defeat a hundred
A hundred shall defeat a thousand
questions.correctAnswer: Five of you shall chase a hundred, and a hundred of you shall put ten thousand to flight
questions.explanation: This promise in Leviticus 26:7-8 highlights God's sovereign protection and empowerment, echoed in Judges 7:7, 1 Samuel 14:6, Psalm 44:3, and Matthew 26:52.

questions.question: What is the significance of God breaking the 'staff of bread' as mentioned in Leviticus 26:26?
options: It symbolizes famine and scarcity, where bread is rationed and unsatisfying
It means the end of agriculture
It promises abundance and prosperity
It indicates a celebration feast
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes famine and scarcity, where bread is rationed and unsatisfying
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:26's breaking of the 'staff of bread' symbolizes severe famine and hardship. This symbolism appears in 2 Kings 7:1, Ezekiel 4:16, Amos 8:11, and Matthew 6:31-33.

questions.question: What does Leviticus 26 teach about God’s holiness and abhorrence toward idolatry?
options: God’s soul shall abhor them and He will destroy their high places
God will tolerate idolatry
God will bless idols as false gods
God will ignore idolatry
questions.correctAnswer: God’s soul shall abhor them and He will destroy their high places
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:30-31 reveals God's abhorrence of idolatry, showing His holiness and intolerance of sin. This is consistent with Exodus 20:5, Deuteronomy 12:31, Psalm 16:4, and 1 Corinthians 10:14.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 26, what will happen to those who are left alive after God's judgments?
options: They will pine away in their iniquity and suffer faintness of heart among enemies
They will quickly be restored without repentance
They will immediately inherit the land
They will be exalted above their enemies
questions.correctAnswer: They will pine away in their iniquity and suffer faintness of heart among enemies
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:36-39 describes survivors suffering faintness and despair because of sin and exile, paralleling Jeremiah 9:15, Ezekiel 12:16, Lamentations 3:46, and Hebrews 12:11.

questions.question: Leviticus 26:1 commands the Israelites not to make certain images. What is the theological reason given?
options: Because I am the LORD your God
Because images are beautiful
Because idols bring prosperity
Because it is a tradition
questions.correctAnswer: Because I am the LORD your God
questions.explanation: Leviticus 26:1 forbids idols because God is the LORD, emphasizing His uniqueness and holiness. This foundational truth is affirmed in Exodus 20:3-5, Deuteronomy 5:7-9, Isaiah 42:8, and John 4:24.
